ratings.comment: Professor Li was one of my favorite psych teachers at UW Madison. The course requires effort, but as long as you do the readings and attend lecture it is manageable. He is very caring towards his students and is quick to respond to any questions. Learned a lot out of this class and was super interesting/engaging. Highly recommend!

Professor Li was OK, but I didn't care for his grade cutoffs. They were unnecessarily high and the coursework and tests were made harder than they needed to be. The overall vibe was not as pleasant as other classes.

Reading the reviews of Dr. Li I was a bit skeptical going into his class. However, despite being a bit fast, I found his lectures to be incredibly interesting. They introduced a lot of new topics but in a way that made them easy to understand and learn. I can see where people think tests are hard but Id you study appropriately youll be fine.

Li was a great lecturer and really helped me get a better understanding of behavioral genetics. All homework facilitates a better understanding of the material. One group project for a "completed vs no completed" grade. 2 oral presentations are required at the end of the semester, so if you don't like public speaking, I'd avoid this class.

Very cynical about the field. Bad aspect: Discourages career pursuit by relating his story of dropping out of med school. Good aspect: worthy psychological critiques. Tough tests, papers. Doesn't seem interested in you as much as his research. Lectures are fascinating. Learned a lot. Put more time in term paper than any paper in college, got a C.

I loved this class with Professor Li! His lectures take textbook information and apply it to real life, questioning how things are and how they can be better. Exams are tough but lecture and discussions give you all the materials you need to do well (short answer is based on discussion activities). Not an easy A class but definitely worth taking.

Wonderful lecturer. You can tell he's extremely passionate about what he lectures. His syllabus details the expectations of the class very clearly. He wants everyone to have a shot at doing well. Don't take this class for an easy A, I am barely scraping by with average grades on exams. So exams are pretty tough.

This was one of my favorite classes at UW. It was incredibly interesting, and Professor Li is clearly very educated in this field. That being said he is very condescending and has little interest in his students unless they are doing well in his class. The class was fair though. I had to put in the work, but I got 100% on most exams.

Some of the topics weren't tackled in the most respectful way, but I learned a lot from this class and it really made me think. It's nice to see a teacher who encourages us to question what we think we know. The tests were worded oddly and unnecessarily specific and no matter how much (or little) I studied my test score never changed from an 85.

Professor Li has really good and engaging lectures. He's great at presenting things in a way you can understand and his powerpoints are well put together. His tests are HARD. They're extremely specific, but it's doable if you pay attention and do the study guides.

Asked the most specific questions you could imagine. Questions can be one small sentence in your book and you are expected to memorize it. I would not recommend if you are not ready to devote an arm and leg to this class. Great at presenting material in interesting way but has way too high of expectations for students.

He lacked consistency. I loved the material and felt I understood it very well (I'm an RA in a developmental psychopathology lab) but he threw random curveballs when it came to difficulty. I went in to office hours once and didn't go back because he was condescending.

I loved this class in the beginning. He puts up the power points that he uses during class. However, he became a lot stricter on what he put on his slides for the third exam because a lot of people stopped coming to class. He also made the last exam extremely difficult, the average was around a 69%.

This was by far my favorite class at UW madison. I learned so much and was excited to attend every lecture. I got pretty much 100% on every exam, but that was because I was deeply interested in child psychopathology and attended every lecture. He is a very engaging professor, I highly recommend this course!

Very effective teacher - better than most professors who've taught for years. He was engaging and approachable. Textbook is useful when not attending lecture or for clarification but is not essential. Test format was inconsistent and the final was extremely difficult, which drove grades way down. But I understand as it was his first semester.

Great professor, especially for his first semester teaching.  Lectures are engaging and incorporate really interesting "bigger picture" info that you don't get in other psych classes.  The textbook is a waste of time but his assigned readings are relevant and interesting.  Tests varied in level of difficulty but you'll do well if you pay attention.

Prof. Li taught Child Psychopathology - super interesting course. Required textbook, but don't need to read it to pass. Extra online readings each week that you DO need to know for exams, but most material is covered in lecture. Discussion section is a grade booster too. One short (2-4 page) paper. Easy A. Would definitely take again.
